MC: In PostgreSQL, what is the main purpose of using a transaction block?

column3: To improve query speed through indexing
To ensure a group of SQL statements execute atomically
To manage data types across multiple tables
To automatically generate audit logs

MC: Which SQL keyword combination marks the beginning and end of a transaction block?

column3: OPEN and CLOSE
BEGIN and COMMIT
CREATE and EXECUTE
START and END

MC: What is the role of a SAVEPOINT in a transaction?

column3: It restarts a transaction after failure
It commits a partial transaction
It allows rollback to a specific intermediate point
It locks the table for concurrent writes

MC: Which command explicitly undoes all changes made in the current transaction?

column3: ROLLBACK
ABORT
UNDO
DELETE

MC: Why are triggers important in database design?

column3: They replace user-defined functions
They automatically generate primary keys
They automate rule enforcement or auditing upon data changes
They make schema migrations faster

MC: What is a common use case for an AFTER INSERT trigger?

column3: To validate a field before data is written
To prevent duplicate entries before insertion
To record the new row in an audit log after it is saved
To enforce default values before insertion

MC: Which trigger timing would be used to validate input before a record is committed to the table?

column3: BEFORE trigger
AFTER trigger
DELAYED trigger
DEFERRED trigger

MC: In PostgreSQL, what happens if an error occurs during a transaction without an exception handler?

column3: The transaction continues but logs an error
The transaction automatically rolls back entirely
The current statement is skipped but others run
The database enters read-only mode

MC: What is the main difference between a function and a procedure in PostgreSQL (since version 11)?

column3: Procedures can use transaction control commands like COMMIT or ROLLBACK
Functions are always faster than procedures
Procedures can return table data directly
Functions cannot be called from SQL

MC: In an auditing system, which of the following best describes idempotency in trigger or procedure design?

column3: Running a trigger multiple times increases accuracy
Executing the same operation multiple times leaves the database in the same state
